lead_paragraph: By the time we reach middle age, it often feels like our brains aren't quite what they used to be. We get distracted, lose car keys and forget the name of the person we just met. Is there a way to train the middle-aged brain to do better? New York Times health editor Barbara Strauch writes:
snippet: By the time we reach middle age, it's clear that our brains aren't quite what they used to be. We get distracted, lose car keys and forget the name of the person we just met. Is there a way to train the middle-aged brain to do better?
abstract: By the time we reach middle age, it's clear that our brains aren't quite what they used to be. We get distracted, lose car keys and forget the name of the person we just met. Is there a way to train the middle-aged brain to do better?
